position.marginalia_text: rubeam, vitellu[m], vitriolum rubeu[m], propter colore[m] rubeu[m] hoc dixerunt. Qui aute[m] no[m]i[n]averunt ip[s]um Ferru[m], Oleum inco[n]bustabile, Oleum martis, propter impotentia[m] fusionis dura[e] hoc dixerunt. Na[m] cum hoc corpus per decoctione[m] privatu[m] sit vna humiditate, qua[e] faciebat ip[s]um fluere, et necesse est corpus siccum no[n] fluere, ideo vocaverunt id, Ferrum: quia inter alia corpora, ferrum d[i]c[itur] maximè fixum. Sic etia[m] istud corpus per privatione[m] humiditatis qua[e] faciebat ip[s]um p[ri]mo volatile, modo est necesse vt remaneat fixum. Na[m] o[mn]ia corpora no[n] fixa, figuntur per tale[m] privatione[m] humiditatis, quae vocata fuit calcinatio, a multis philosophis. Vnde inquit Geber. Calcinatio est rei per igne[m] purificatio, seu pulverizatio, ex privatione humiditatis, partes co[n]solidantis, et fluere facientis. Et causa inventio[n]is calcinationis spirituum est, vt ibi melius signatur. Sic ergo fit per privatione[m] humidiatis volatile fixu[m], et molle durum. Item fit mutatio de natura in natura[m]. et aqua[e] in igne[m], secundu[m] naturales Philosophos, vt scribitur in turba Philosophoru[m]. Ite[m] mutatio complexionu[m], vt frigida[e] et humida[e] complexionis in calida[m] et sicca[m], seu phlegmatica[e] co[m]plexionis in Cholerica[m], secundu[m] medicos. Item fit spirituale corporeu[m] secundu[m] Authore[m] perfecti magisterij. Ite[m]

book.title: The Height of the Perfection of Mastery

marginalia.translation:
Red [soil], calf/yolk, red vitriol, because of its red colour they said. But these they names iron, , oil of Mars, because of the weakness of dry fusion they say. For when this body is through decoction deprived of humidity, which makes itself flow, and it is necessary that the body does not flow, therefore they called it iron, because among these bodies iron is said to be the most concrete. Thus, through the deprivation of humidity, which makes it volatile initially, this body is necessary to remain concrete. For no body is concrete and they are established for such deprivation of humidity, which was called calcination by many philosophers. About this Geber said: Calcination is purification of a thing through fire or pulverisation from the deprivation of humidity, which makes the parts consolitade or makes them fluid. And the reason for the intervention of calcination of spirits is that it is better described here.
Item the mutation from nature to nature happens. And of water into fire, according to the natural philosophers, as is written in the Assembly of Philosophers. Likewise, the mutation of the constitutions, like of cold and wet constitution into hot and dry, or of phlegmatic constitution into choleric, according to the physicians. Likewise according to the author of The Height of the Perfection of Mastery. Also [...].
